emphasis.docTitle: Sarcophagidae ( Insecta : Diptera ) of Saudi Arabia : new records, an updated checklist and a new species

subSection.paragraph: HASSAN A. DAWAH 1 , MOHAMMED A. ABDULLAH 2 & THOMAS PAPE 3 *

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Centre for Environmental Research and Studies, Jazan University, P.O. Box 2095, Jazan , Kingdom of Saudi Arabia .
Department of Biology, College of Science, King Khalid University, PO Box 9004, Abha-61413, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia .
Natural History Museum of Denmark , Universitetsparken 15, 2100 Copenhagen, Denmark .

subSection.paragraph:
As part of a study on the biodiversity of Diptera of south-western Saudi Arabia , a survey of the Diptera fauna of Jazan , Asir and Najran at 10 sites was performed between 2012–2015 mainly using Malaise traps, sweep nets and baited traps. A total of 21 species of Sarcophagidae are recorded and documented with photographs, seven of which represent new country records for Saudi Arabia . Including species with a reliable previous record from Saudi Arabia , the total number of species of Sarcophagidae known from Saudi Arabia now stands at 51. All species of Sarcophagidae recorded from Saudi Arabia are listed, including distributions and the source where species were first recorded. Material studied as part of the project resulted in 16 new country records for other countries.
Alusomyia Villeneuve, 1933
is here synonymized with
Hoplacephala Macquart, 1834
,
syn. nov.
, argued from the presence of four proclinate orbital bristles, the row of strong parafacial setae close to the anteroventral eye-margin, the large gena and the robust habitus compared to most other miltogrammines. The generic synonomy requires the new combinations
Hoplacephala transfuga ( Villeneuve, 1933 )
,
comb. nov.
and
Hoplacephala turana ( Rohdendorf, 1975 )
,
comb. nov.
Sarcophaga surcoufi Villeneuve, 1913
is synonymized with
Engelisca adhamae Lehrer & Abou-Zied, 2008
,
syn. nov.
An appendix authored by Dr J.C. Deeming contains the description of
Sarcophaga dawahi Deeming
,
sp. nov.
Key words : Biodiversity survey , faunistics , flesh flies , nomenclature , taxonomy

The first records of Sarcophagidae from Saudi Arabia may be those of
Apodacra sp.
,
Sarcophaga destructor Malloch, 1929
and
Sarcophaga falculata Pandellé, 1896
[
Sarcophaga argyrostoma ( Robineau-Desvoidy, 1830 )
] mentioned by Shalaby (1961) . Since then, new records of species have appeared in various publications, in particular those of Al-Ahmadi & Salem (1999) ,
Büttiker et al . (1979)
, Dabbour (1979a ,b), Amoudi (1993) ,
Al-Misned et al . (2001)
, Dawah & Abdullah (2005) , Lehrer & Abou-Zied (2008) ,
Zaglool et al . (2013)
,
El-Hawagry et al. (2013
, 2016 , 2017 , 2018). Most recently, Verves & Khrokalo (2018) listed 27 species from Saudi Arabia and provided more specific details and several new country records in a series of papers (
Verves & Khrokalo 2020 a
,b, 2021).

The objective of the present paper is to present the flesh flies obtained from a study on Diptera diversity of south-western Saudi Arabia and to provide an updated checklist of the species of family Sarcophagidae known from Saudi Arabia .

As part of a study on the biodiversity of Diptera of south-western Saudi Arabia , insect specimens were collected, mainly using Malaise traps and sweep nets, at 10 sites in Jazan , Asir and Najran provinces of Saudi Arabia ( Table 1 ). Specimens were collected using Malaise traps and sweep nets during 2001–2004 and 2012–2015, and in the latter period also with sticky yellow traps and traps baited with 200 g of decomposing fish and bovine liver (exposed for 24 hours at room temperature prior to use), which were suspended 0.8–2.1 m above the ground on a livestock farm Mohammed Bakreen ( Table 1 ). The Malaise traps were situated in a variety of habitats, and at various altitudes up to 2526 meters above sea level. The habitats included a rather barren coastal plain subject to seasonal rains, wadies and mountain pastures. The vegetation ranged from native plants, fruit trees, vegetable crops, field crops, fodder crops, woods and ornamental trees, and a commercial nursery ( Figs 1–6 ). Wherever possible, traps were located in farms where they could be protected. The farms were visited at three-week intervals to collect the insect samples and add ethanol to the collecting containers; at other times farm workers would maintain ethanol levels in the containers as needed. Sarcophagidae were sorted from the samples, passed through grades of alcohol to absolute ethanol and placed in ethyl acetate for a few days before being air dried to re-establish their patterns of microtomentum. Specimens were pinned and labelled before being studied.

Most identifications were done by Dr.J.C.Deeming, at the National Museum of Wales,Cardiff ( NMWC ).Voucher specimens have been deposited in the National Museum of Wales, Cardiff ( NMWC ), Centre for Environmental research and Studies, Jazan University, Saudi Arabia ( CERS ), Natural History Museum, London ( NHMUK ) and Natural History Museum of Denmark , Copenhagen ( NHMDK ). The species account is arranged by subfamilies and with species in alphabetic order. Each entry gives the valid name of the species followed by the correct original spelling of the original combination with authorship and type locality, and with the addition of synonymies where this is considered helpful. Specimens examined for the present study are listed with all label data (standardised rather than verbatim) plus the relevant depository, and the general distribution by country is given in alphabetical order. A concluding paragraph gives the reference found in this study with the first mention of the species from Saudi Arabia and any other remarks considered of relevance. Specimens were identified to species level mainly using Zumpt (1965) , Rohdendorf (1930 , 1937 , 1959 , 1970 ), and Verves (1982 – 1993 ) as well as by comparison with reliably identified specimens in NMWC and NHMDK . Preparation of male terminalia follows Dawah & Abdullah (2006) .
Abu-Zoherah et al. (1993: 228)
listed all the species of insects present in the National Agriculture and Water Research Centre, Riyadh , Saudi Arabia , but no Sarcophagidae were marked as being present in this collection, which unfortunately has not been available for study.

Species recorded from Saudi Arabia in the literature but considered in this study to be misidentifications, and species listed from Saudi Arabia in the literature but only known from the Socotra archipelago, which is today a governorate of Yemen , have been listed in square brackets and are not counted as being Saudi Arabian.

Yan et al. (2021a)
. New country records are marked with an asterisk for the respective countries under the paragraph ‘Distribution’.

Twenty two species of Sarcophagidae were identified from the field-collected material ( Figs 2–23 ), seven of which represent new country records for Saudi Arabia . This raises the total number of species of Sarcophagidae known from Saudi Arabia to 51. Additional material studied as part of the present study resulted in 16 new records for other countries. One species new to science,
Sarcophaga dawahi Deeming
sp. nov.
, is described in an Appendix.

Distribution. Egypt , Niger , Saudi Arabia *.

Remarks. First record from Saudi Arabia . The genus
Alusomyia Villeneuve, 1933
is distinctive as currently defined by largely yellow coloration, strongly reduced mouthparts, an irregular row of bristly setae close to the anteroventral eye-margin, and wing cell R 4+5 closed or with very short petiole ( Rohdendorf 1975 ; Pape 1996 ). Each of the four nominal species included were based exclusively on a single male, the holotype , and Pape (1996) considered these to constitute two valid species. No further males have been reported in the literature, and the present report is the first record of a female.
Alusomyia Villeneuve, 1933
is here synonymized with
Hoplacephala Macquart, 1834
,
syn. nov.
, argued from the presence of four proclinate orbital bristles, the row of strong parafacial setae close to the anteroventral eye-margin, the large gena, and the somewhat robust habitus compared to most other miltogrammines. The generic synonymy evokes the new combinations
Hoplacephala transfuga ( Villeneuve, 1933 )
,
comb. nov.
and
Hoplacephala turana ( Rohdendorf, 1975 )
comb. nov.

Specimens examined.
SAUDI ARABIA : 1♂ , Asir , Maraba , Al-Hudaithy Fruit Farm ,
1–17.vi.2003
, Malaise trap , H.A. Dawah ( NMWC )
.

Remarks. The genus
Miltogramma Meigen
has not previously been recorded from Saudi Arabia . A reliable identification of the specimen awaits comparisons with relevant material across the Middle East.
Miltogramma
in the broad sense of Pape (1996) and further revised by
Szpila et al. (2023)
is a large Old World genus, currently with some 120 described species. The taxon has been split into several subunits, which have variously been given rank of genus or subgenus depending on the generic concepts applied (e.g., Verves 1989 ), and the present species would appear to fit the concept of either
Pediasiomyia Rohdendorf
or
Rhynchapodacra Rohdendorf
as keyed by Verves (1994) . We are here accepting the broad concept of
Miltogramma
as applied by
Johnston et al. (2023)
and
Szpila et al. (2023)
.

and

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. Albania , Armenia , Azerbaijan, Bulgaria , China , Croatia , Czech Republic , Egypt , France , Georgia, Hungary , India , Iran , Israel , Italy , Kazakhstan , Moldova , Pakistan , Romania , Russia , Saudi Arabia , Slovakia , South Africa , Spain , Tajikistan Turkmenistan , Turkey , Ukraine , Uzbekistan , Zaire.

Remarks. First record from Saudi Arabia found in this study is by Verves & Khrokalo (2018 , as
Liosarcophaga parkeri ( Rohdendorf, 1937 ))
. The nominal taxa
Sarcophaga aegyptica Salem, 1935
and
Parasarcophaga parkeri Rohdendorf
have variously been considered as distinct species (e.g., Pape 1996 ;
El-Ahmady et al. 2018
, Verves & Khrokalo 2018 ) or synonyms (e.g.,
Richet et al. 2011
;
Krčmar et al. 2019
,
Wang et al. 2022
). We are here siding with the latter, awaiting evidence from molecular data.

paragraph.emphasis: Species previously reported from Saudi Arabia but not included in the checklist:

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. Listed from Saudi Arabia by
Al Dhafer et al. (2011)
, but this is probably a misidentification as no species of
Angiometopa Brauer & Bergenstamm
has so far been recorded south of the 40th parallel north ( Pape 1996 ). A female of the genus
Wohlfahrtia Brauer & Bergenstamm
may be involved, but the voucher for this record could not be traced.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Musca devia
Fallén, 1820: 6
. Type locality: Sweden [probably Skåne ].

subSubSection.paragraph: Remarks. Listed from Saudi Arabia by Verves & Khrokalo (2018) . In need of confirmation as the record was a listing in a table with no data for any voucher specimen and without being indicated as a new country record.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Musca carnaria
Linnaeus, 1758: 596
. Type locality: Europe [probably Sweden ].

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. Listed from SaudiArabia by
Kenawy et al. (2014)
, but this is probably a misidentification as
Sarcophaga carnaria
so far has not been recorded south of the 40th parallel north ( Pape 1996 ). The record of
Sarcophaga carnaria
from Saudi Arabia was accepted by Verves & Khrokalo (2018) , but considering the nomenclatural complexities ( Pape 2002 ), the numerous misidentifications in older material, and the lack of reference to voucher specimens by
Kenawy et al . (2014)
, the presence of this species in Saudi Arabia is in need of verification.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Sarcophaga cincta Villeneuve, 1910
in Becker, 1910: 146 . Type locality: Yemen, Socotra Archipelago, Samḥah I.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. Listed from Yemen (Socotra) as part of Saudi Arabia by Abu-Zoherah et al . (1993, as
Pseudodiscachaeta cincta
without further data). The nominal species, which is known only from the type locality, is in need of a taxonomic revision (Pape 1996), but it has not been possible to trace the type material. The nominal species may represent a species of the genus
Blaesoxipha Loew
[“La tête étant conformée comme chez
Sarc. lineata Fall.
[=
Blaesoxipha lapidosa Pape
], il n’est pas impossible que cette espèce prenne place un jour dans le s.genre Gesneriades” (Villeneuve 1910: 146)]. The nominal species was not mentioned by Verves & Khrokalo (2018).

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Sarcophaga pedestris Villeneuve, 1910: 147
. Type locality: Yemen , Socotra Archipelago, Socotra , Ra’s Farták.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. Listed from “ Saudi Arabia , Socotra ” by Verves (1986a) and from Saudi Arabia with no further data by
Abu-Zoherah et al . (1993
, as
Pseudodiscachaeta pedestris
). The nominal species, which is known only from the type locality, is in need of a taxonomic revision ( Pape 1996 ), but it has not been possible to trace the type material. The nominal species was placed in the genus-group taxon
Liosarcophaga Enderlein
by Verves & Khrokalo (2018) , which is accepted here.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Sarcophaga trifolia
Villeneuve, 1910
in
Becker, 1910: 146
. Type locality: Yemen , Socotra Archipelago, Socotra , Ra’s Shoab.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. Yemen ( Socotra ).

Remarks. Listed from Saudi Arabia by
Abu-Zoherah et al . (1993
, as
Pseudodiscachaeta trifolia
without further data). The nominal species is only known from the type locality, and it is in in need of a taxonomic revision ( Pape 1996 ), but it has not been possible to trace the type material. The nominal species was not mentioned by Verves & Khrokalo (2018) .

subSection.paragraph:
This project was supported by the King Abdul Aziz City for Science and Technology, grant number (AT-32-0023), Saudi Arabia , for which we are very grateful. The funders had no role in the study design, data collection and analysis, decision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript. Our sincere thanks are due to the following institutions and people, without whose kind help this paper would not have been completed: Jazan University for providing research facilities; Dr. Mohammed Oteef, supervisor of the Centre for Environmental Research and Studies, for all his support and encouragement; Dr. J.C. Deeming, for his help in identification, commenting on the manuscript and taxonomic advice, and for having generously and untiringly provided his help to HAD and MAA throughout the studies leading to the present work [JCD humbly wished not to be co-author of this paper and to only contribute as the author of the new species of
Sarcophaga
. We take this opportunity to express our most heartfelt thanks for his instrumental guidance]; Dr. D. Whitmore, Natural History Museum, London (now Naturkundemuseum Stuttgart), for help in identification; Dr. B. Levey for photographing some specimens; Dr. S.K. Ahmad, for his great help, contribution, enthusiasm and hard work to improve the manuscript; Mrs. H.J. Dawah for checking the English; Mr. G. Jervis and Mr. M. Bouka for their help with literature searches; National Museum of Wales for access to facilities and permission to use the insect collection; Jazan Agriculture Research Centre for facilities and permission to deploy Malaise traps in the fields of the Centre; Mr. A. R . Hobany and Mr O.S. Sanlocan for technical assistance and help in the field; Mr. S. Makbol, Mr. S. Al-Rahela Al-Kahtani and his family for allowing us to deploy Malaise traps on their farms and for taking care of them during this project.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined.
Holotype 1♂ , SAUDI ARABIA : Asir , Abha , Hay Al-Nusub ,
12.v–3.vi.2015
, Malaise trap , H.A. Dawah ( NMWC )
.

All paratypes collected in Malaise traps by H.A. Dawah and dry-mounted ( CERS , NMWC , NHMDK , NHMUK )
.

Description. A black species with black bristles and with terminalia in both sexes more or less reddish, mesonotum with the usual five dark longitudinal vittae interspersed with grey dusted vittae, abdomen dorsally with a strongly contrasted tesselated pattern, this and the silver and black pattern of the fronto-orbital plate, parafrontal plate, gena and postocular strip changing according to the incidence of light; wing hyaline with epaulet black and basicosta yellow, the veins strongly yellow towards base, becoming more brownish towards apex, the anterior crossvein totally hidden within a deep black patch, the posterior cross-vein weakly and narrowly infuscate; lower calypter and haltere yellowish white.

Male. Body length = 7.0– 8.3 mm ; wing length = 5.5–7.0 mm; head lacking pale bristles or setae; frons at widest part in male 0.29 x width of head, in female 0.40; arista plumose on basal half. Thorax: with proanepisternum bare; mesonotum with 1 long prescutellar dorsocentral bristle closely preceded by a much weaker one of only half its length, a similar weak dorsocentral situated just presuturally; no acrostichal bristles differentiated from the intradorsocentral setulae. Wing dorsally with a row of setae extending from node of vein R 4+5 two thirds of length to anterior cross vein, ventrally the node bearing a brush of c. 4–5 setae; bend of M acute, forming an angle of c. 80°; posterior crossvein sinuous. Legs with apical half of mid femur on anteroventral surface with an open comb of rather fine bristles that are as long as the mid tibia is wide, and level with these posteroventrally with a row of 7 shorter, almost spatulate bristles; hind femur with a row of very long anteroventral bristles, posteroventrally with fine long setae; hind tibia long setose anteroventrally, ventrally and posteroventrally. Abdomen often with reddish coloration extending onto apical half of tergite 5; tergite 1+2 with a single lateral marginal bristle, tergite 3 with 1–2 lateral, tergite 4 with 3 lateral and 2 medial marginals and tergite 5 with complete row of strong marginal bristles, none on protandrial segment ( Fig. 39 ); cerci ( Fig. 40 ) tapering and diverging apically, bearing only fine setae; distiphallus ( Figs 42–43 ) with sclerites black, apart from vesica, which is milk white in dry specimens; sternite 5 ( Fig. 41 ) narrow, with narrow arms, strong bristles concentrated at inner base of lobes and with a few very long setae; ejaculatory apodeme with narrow blade, slightly widened apically, and oval basal bulb that in length is two thirds that of blade.

Female. Resembling male, apart from sexual differences of terminalia and sternite 5, with mid femur having preapical anteroventral and posteroventral bristles similar and lacking the long setosity of the hind leg.
Etymology. Dedicated to Prof. H.A. Dawah for his considerable contributions to the knowledge of the entomology of Saudi Arabia .

Remarks.
Sarcophaga dawahi
resembles species of
Sarcophaga
subgenus
Poecilometopa Villeneuve
by its wing markings, but it has a bare proanepisternum. Placing
S. dawahi
in a subgenus should await a more detailed analysis of the subgeneric classification of the large genus
Sarcophaga
. This species runs to
Sarcophaga tanzaniae Zumpt
in Zumpt’s (1972: 193–195) key but differs from this species in lacking a pair of medial marginal bristles on tergite 3, in having the hind tibia long setose anteroventrally and posteroventrally, and in having only two pairs of postsutural dorsocentral bristles. The altitudes of collecting localities are: Bani Mazen, 2199 m ; Madinate Al-Ameer Sultan; 2042 m ; Hay Al-Nusub, 2199 m ; Hay Al-Menhel, 2150 m ; Hay Al-Shurfa, 1261 m ; Al-Mahdag Village,
80 m .
Considering the large number of samples taken over a period of time and at a range of localities, this appears to be an uncommon species with a preference for higher altitudes.
